comments.commentBody: Asa 55 yr old independent voter, the nation's polarity is just where it should be...down the middle.  To say that we are swinging left is based on the fact that the extreme right has darkened the poltical waters so much over the past decade or so. For the Democrats, the recent vote in Massachusetts is the political equivalent of the aborted terrorist attempt on Christmas Day. Hopefully, they will wake up, connect the dots, and act decisively to anticipate and forestall any more events like that in the future. That many citizens of Massachusetts would chose to vote for the Republican shows (1) that they have a very short memory of the complete failures over the past 8 years of GOP dominance that brought us to our current sad state, (2) that instilling fear and hatred is still an effective tool for right-wing extremist politicians, and (3) that the Democrats are clueless.  As far as the administration is concerned however, President Obama was faced with several Herculean tasks when he entered office a year ago and receives an "A" for his efforts so far in my grade book.

For an allegedly enlightened state, the Democrats have chosen over the past few decades to send two rich, white men to represent them.

Up until Martha Coakley was nominted, am I to conclude that there are no minorities in Massachusetts and that all are as wealthy as the Kennedy and Kerry families?

It's frustrating to know that this country finally started to address it's challenges in a rational and intelligent way but is already eager to run back to the rational and unitelligent way it's been facing it's challenges since the mid-1970's. It's actually a replay of the 1970's and early 1980's.

When the problems became great and the solutions unpleasant the Republicans simply promised the people an easy way out and denial of all the problems. It worked well politically but it didn't fix anything. They could do this because the United States was so huge an economic and military power that other countries were eager to give us a line of credit that was basically unlimited. They cut taxes and government and regulations, and just let whatever happen, happen.

It did not turn out badly overtime, it started out badly. The infrastructure of our entire country began to wear down and out because of a lack of maintenance. The lack of regulations led to the Saving and Loan scandal and a huge taxpayer bailout. We increased our military spending while we were borrowing money to avoid raising taxes to pay for government. We could do this and watch our productive economy shrink for the workers because we started out so wealthy and backed by foreign credit that we could pay for all the mistakes and not have to face a reckoning. There were problems with these policies but the Republican refused to accept the evidence that they were mistaken.

Now we face a future in which our prospects for continue wealth and prosperity are not good. But our reaction is to oppose changes that are drastic and require a long term commitment, not realizing that these are the easy solutions, the ones we can manage. If we wait until it gets really bad, we won't have the resources to respond as well as we can, now.

The Republicans do not offer any solutions. Cutting taxes and reducing government authority to regulate industries and privatizing government services have all been tried for nearly four decades. These notions have not lead to growth and prosperity for all, they have redistributed wealth and left this country poorer overall.

Scott Brown is definitely the kinda guy I would not be surprised to be in line with at Popeye's - he and his truck are of the people just as the sailor-man is...lets only hope that a fast-food fried-chicken stand is added to the Senate food-court post-haste...Teddy would have wanted this!

My neighbors and I are tired of the Harry and Nancy show. Cooperation? The Democrats can't even cooperate with themselves, let alone Republicans. Harry's favorite question is "What do you need so that I can get your vote? Money is no object." Nancy seems to believe we are all from San Francisco, or at least should be. Were you elected to ram a progressive agenda through Congress, or to consider all points of view, even... gasp!... that Republicans might have a few good ideas like tort reform. We are weary of posturing, spin, and backroom deals. We are not children. No major legislation affecting so many people as health insurance "reform" should be enacted without some reasonable level of bi[partisan support.

Democrats are simply are too weak to hold office.  They can't bring themselves to say bad things about Republicans even when it’s true. Rush Limbaugh said that Obama is planning to set up a Cuba like Communist dictatorship, destroy all private enterprise, and crush free speech the democrats don't even have enough self respect to disagree. They won’t point out that undermining the authority of the President in time of war is unpatriotic. They can't even bring themselves to point out that the Republicans and the right ruined the economy. Republicans never take responsibility for anything that they do and the Democrats never call them on it. There is no better proof that Democrats are weak willed cowards then when the Republicans blamed Democrat Barney Frank for the whole mortgage collapse even though the Republican Party held both houses of Congress, the Presidency, and most judgeships. Poor Barney was the only one who spoke up for himself and the rest of the Democrats hung him out to dry.

We have all just witnessed the most stunning collapse of political power and promise in at least the last 100 years. We have witnessed the immolation of the Obama agenda at the hands of an aroused populace. In order for Obama to salvage anything he needs to go before the people at the State of the Union and admit that he made horrendous mistakes in his first year and ask for forgiveness. He must promise to work with the center including Republicans, practice transparency and put the public first. The American people are very forgiving when one admits error forthrightly and then actually follows up with real change in governance. If he did this and then shook up his administration so the political suits no longer ran everything he has a chance of regaining the peoples trust.
Obama, I fear, is much too arrogant to do this and we will all suffer as a result as the ship of state wanders confusedly during perilous times.

Donna Brazile, it may have been on a bumper sticker when you were a child, nevertheless, it was Will Rogers who said, "I don't belong to any organized political party.  I'm a Democrat." Both parties must learn that getting 50-55% of the vote is not a mandate. Of those who vote for you, there is often a large portion of people who disagree with major policies and issues of the candidate for whom they voted. Compromise doesn't always create a poor product.

Poster #97:  "Brown had the charisma to excite people who don't typically vote and the money and lies of the national Republican party fully behind him."  Change the names to Obama and the Democratic party and you'll understand why change is coming in November.  Obama was elected for his charisma, nothing more, nothing less.  It simply took awhile for independents to wake up and realize their mistake in electing an unknown.  Hillary would have been so much better.

Obama doesn't seem to know how to lead his party. He seems much too interested in cutting deals with special interests, in order to get things done. He completely jumped the shark when the unions got a 5 year or so wavier on health benefit taxes.

Until the leader of his party learns how to get some party discipline, the democrats will continue to lose whatever narrow gains they made in 2008.

Like Felix from NY (#21) said,

> Ideology is also a factor. Impeding government action (i.e., the filibuster) is seen by the public as consistent with conservative ideology, which values restraining government action. Thus, guys like Oklahoma Senator Tom Coburn are admired for encouraging the government NOT to do things, as it were. On the other side, use of the filibuster by liberals looks to the public simply like pouting.

The Democrats need to learn to say to the Republicans and the country, LEAD, FOLLOW OR GET OUT OF THE WAY. All the Republicans have been doing is standing IN THE WAY throwing bricks through the windows of government. They're expert at this; after all, they are the party that hates government and wants to destroy it. The Democrats need to point them out as the vandals they are, and say it loud and clear.

Who wins when there is no government? The RICH and the MOBS. Oh look! The Republican Party's owners - and so-called base.

If Democrats start pointing this out loud and clear, most ordinary Americans will realize that it's the truth.

Meanwhile, the Democrats had better start getting RID of all the Republicans-in-all-but-name that they recruited in the last 10 years to become like the Republicans. Including the creeps from my state, who look exactly like the four idiots in the picture above: old, rich greedy white guys scrambling for lobbyists' money, out of touch with today's world, and utterly unwilling to do anything for the average unemployed people back home.

Democrats in office reflect ordinary democratically -minded people. We don't really like the
trappings, expected behavior, or arrogance of those with power, or maybe even like holding power
even if we may be seduced by the abstract idea. How do you pull together with a large bunch of people who you don't like very much, and really don't want to become one of ?

Wow, this sounds so familiar, except that this happened to me on Direct TV.  My friend signed up for the Jade TV after being told it was part of a certain package.  On the first bill she received, she was billed almost twice the agreed upon price.  Basically, the sales rep lied about what was included on the bundle.  With English being her second language, she was very frustrated by Direct TV's refusal to uphold the original agreement.  I was asked to help her talk with customer service to see if we could come to some sort of resolution.  After talking to a "service" rep  and escalating the phone call to a supervisor, I was told that even if the sales rep misrepresented the package, my friend was still on the hook for the contract.  So to lower her bill, she kept the Jade TV but switched to a lower plan.  She was also promised an extra discount that was good for 6 months and then she could request the extra discount to be extended for another 6 months.  Sufficed to say, every month, I would have to call the "customer service" because the various discounts were not properly applied.  I would first speak to a service rep, then to a supervisor who would promise to put back the discounts.  After 4 months of this, a supervisor finally refused to apply the credit.  The real frustration is that they would never send a written confirmation of what was agreed upon.  They supposedly documented every phone call and even gave us a confirmation number.  Yet every month, I would have to call and do my little song and dance.  Finally, I told my friend to write a letter to the FCC and to cc Direct TV.  An executive in the customer service department contacted my friend and as I recall basically offered 1/2 the agreed upon discounts and said that was all they were going to offer and if she did not like it, she could cancel the service but would still be responsible for the cancellation fee.  Well, my friend is no longer with Direct TV but is now with Comcast.

My problem for a long time was that I decoded the missing corner was "don't get", as in "don't get personal" and "don't get fancy".  But I eventually got over that, and enjoyed the aha moment quite a bit.  Question, though - wouldn't brevipennate mean "short feathered", not "short winged"?
Um...er...why not just say no? Isn't that what adults are supposed to do?
